üîç Querying

Master BLite's powerful LINQ-based query engine with automatic index optimization.

Basic Queries

var results = users.AsQueryable()
    .Where(u => u.Age > 25)
    .AsEnumerable();

foreach (var user in results)
{
    Console.WriteLine(user.Name);
}

Filtering

Comparison Operators

// Equality
.Where(u => u.Name == "Alice")

// Greater than / Less than
.Where(u => u.Age > 30)
.Where(u => u.Age <= 50)

// Range
.Where(u => u.Age >= 18 && u.Age <= 65)

String Operations

// StartsWith (optimized with B-Tree index)
.Where(u => u.Name.StartsWith("A"))

// Contains (full scan)
.Where(u => u.Email.Contains("@example.com"))

// Case-insensitive
.Where(u => u.Name.ToLower() == "alice")

Logical Operators

// AND
.Where(u => u.Age > 25 && u.Name.StartsWith("A"))

// OR
.Where(u => u.Age < 18 || u.Age > 65)

// NOT
.Where(u => !(u.Age >= 18 && u.Age <= 65))

Sorting

// Ascending
.OrderBy(u => u.Age)

// Descending
.OrderByDescending(u => u.Name)

// Multiple sort keys
.OrderBy(u => u.Age)
.ThenBy(u => u.Name)

Pagination

int page = 2;
int pageSize = 10;

var results = users.AsQueryable()
    .OrderBy(u => u.Id)
    .Skip((page - 1) * pageSize)
    .Take(pageSize)
    .AsEnumerable();

Projection

Select Specific Fields

var names = users.AsQueryable()
    .Select(u => u.Name)
    .AsEnumerable();

// Anonymous types
var summary = users.AsQueryable()
    .Select(u => new { u.Name, u.Age })
    .AsEnumerable();

Push-down Projection NEW in v1.5.0

When a query contains only scalar-field projections, BLite compiles the SELECT lambda into a single-pass raw-BSON reader. The source type T is never instantiated ‚Äî only the requested bytes are read off the page.

// Only Name and Age bytes are read ‚Äî User is never allocated
var dtos = users.AsQueryable()
    .Select(u => new UserDto(u.Name, u.Age))
    .ToList();

// WHERE + SELECT: both evaluated in a single BSON pass
var adults = users.AsQueryable()
    .Where(u => u.Age >= 18)
    .Select(u => new { u.Name, u.Age })
    .ToList();
‚ö° When push-down fires: SELECT with scalar fields only, with or without a WHERE clause. Queries that include OrderBy / Take / Skip after the projection still benefit ‚Äî the ordering/paging is applied on the already-projected IEnumerable<TResult>. Complex/nested fields (e.g. x.Address) automatically fall back to the standard path.

Async LINQ v1.4.0+

AsQueryable() returns IBLiteQueryable<T>, which preserves the async chain across all LINQ operators.

// Async terminal operators
var list  = await users.AsQueryable().Where(u => u.Age > 25).ToListAsync();
var count = await users.AsQueryable().CountAsync();
var any   = await users.AsQueryable().AnyAsync(u => u.Active);

// Async streaming via IAsyncEnumerable<T>
await foreach (var user in users.AsQueryable().Where(u => u.Age > 25).AsAsyncEnumerable())
{
    Console.WriteLine(user.Name);
}

Aggregations

// Count
var total = users.AsQueryable().Count();
var adults = users.AsQueryable().Count(u => u.Age >= 18);

// Sum, Min, Max, Average
var totalAge = users.AsQueryable().Sum(u => u.Age);
var youngest = users.AsQueryable().Min(u => u.Age);
var oldest = users.AsQueryable().Max(u => u.Age);
var avgAge = users.AsQueryable().Average(u => u.Age);

GroupBy

var byAge = users.AsQueryable()
    .GroupBy(u => u.Age)
    .Select(g => new
    {
        Age = g.Key,
        Count = g.Count(),
        Names = g.Select(u => u.Name).ToList()
    })
    .AsEnumerable();

Index Optimization

BLite automatically uses B-Tree indexes when available:

// Create an index on Age
users.EnsureIndex(u => u.Age);

// This query now uses the index
var results = users.AsQueryable()
    .Where(u => u.Age > 30) // ‚Üê Index hit!
    .AsEnumerable();

// Enum properties can also be indexed (v1.7.0)
orders.EnsureIndex(o => o.Status);
var shipped = orders.AsQueryable()
    .Where(o => o.Status == OrderStatus.Shipped)
    .AsEnumerable();
üí° Tip: Use .Explain() to see query execution plans and verify index usage. Enum index keys are stored as their underlying integer value (int, byte, long) ‚Äî ordering and range queries work correctly.

Advanced Examples

Complex Filter

var results = users.AsQueryable()
    .Where(u => 
        u.Age >= 25 && 
        u.Age <= 50 && 
        u.Name.StartsWith("A") &&
        u.Email.Contains("@company.com")
    )
    .OrderBy(u => u.Age)
    .ThenBy(u => u.Name)
    .Take(100)
    .AsEnumerable();
